content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 3 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Similarly, if I pick B in round one and my opponent chooses R, I earn 40$. Again, since there are still two more rounds to go, I have a chance to recover some losses if they change their strategy in the following rounds. On the other hand, if both of us pick B in round one, we each earn 20$ (total: 40$).

Given that I don't know my opponent's strategy and there are three rounds, I would start by picking R in round one to maximize the potential earnings if they choose B in subsequent rounds. If they consistently choose R, I can adjust my strategy accordingly to optimize my payoff in the remaining rounds.
